Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Human Fibrinogen Concentrate in Aortic Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive FCH or placebo.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility included patients with a 5 min bleeding mass of 60–250 g after separation from bypass and surgical haemostasis.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive FCH or placebo.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the haemostatic efficacy of single-dose human fibrinogen concentrate (FCH) in patients undergoing elective aortic surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of allogeneic blood product units transfused within 24 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 519 patients were randomised, with 260 to FCH and 259 to placebo, between January 2010 and December 2012.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of these, 152 met the criteria for study medication.

Result_Outcome.evidence: More blood products were transfused in the FCH group (median 5.0 units) compared to placebo (median 3.0 units), p = 0.026.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups.
